body: In the imagination of Wanda James, the story goes something like this: A small group of soldiers returns to Brooklyn from Iraq. One of them proposes to his longtime girlfriend, with whom he had fathered a girl just before his deployment. The wedding and reception last two weeks, stretching from Dec. 16 to New Year's Day. The setting is the same
title: It May Not Be Macy's, but This Window Still Draws a Crowd

body: Metho Nelson would be the first to say that he has been favored with many acts of kindness in his 23 years. But there are four gifts, he said, that truly stand out. First: the day when, after being put out of his Brooklyn home at age 18, he encountered two New York police officers in Prospect Park. They had noticed Mr. Nelson wandering, bench to
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; In Acts of Kindness, a Chance at a New Start

body: Bumper Cars Cobble Hill is a neighborhood of old brownstones and narrow streets. It also has a hospital and nursing home whose employees often wait in their cars and save spaces for friends on the next shift -- an annoying but not illegal practice. What must be illegal, though, is cramming one's car into too small a space. Having witnessed this one
title: COMPLAINT BOX; And Another Thing...

body: ON a recent frigid Thursday night about 300 people sipped wine, knitted and tapped their feet as they listened to the music of the ZigZag Quartet. The evening was notable for the group's range -- from classical to jazz to Brazilian samba -- and because it took place at Lincoln Center's newest space, the David Rubenstein Atrium, which officially
title: As Good as Having an Uncle in the Business

body: THE first time Todd and Marlene Capron saw their two-bedroom rental apartment in Brooklyn, they were horrified. ''The floorboards were cracked, the kitchen was awful, paint was peeling, the ceiling was a mess and there was a lot of damage to the brick wall,'' said Mr. Capron, 31. And then there was the bathroom. ''The faucets were leaky, the tile
title: Renovating a Rental As if It Were Their Own

body: Through the real estate boom, few new developers filled the city with luxury condominiums as fast as Shaya Boymelgreen. He turned Wall Street corner offices into minimalist bachelor lairs, built TriBeCa apartments snapped up by celebrities like Gwyneth Paltrow and crowded the edges of Park Slope, Brooklyn, with condos. But Mr. Boymelgreen, 58, has
title: Star of Real Estate Boom Is Confronting Hard Times

body: A lot of people cry over their hard-luck stories. Dominique Wright wants to write about hers. She started her first journal at 8 years old, while living with a foster mother in South Jamaica, Queens, because her own mother had turned to drugs and alcohol and could not keep her six children at that time. At 12, her father regained custody of her and
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Chronicling a Life and Honing Job Skills

body: NEW YORK ON LESS: Finances Flabby? Tighten the Body Just because your bank account has lost some of its muscle does not mean your body has to suffer the same fate. Take Charlene Bryant, 45, who has lost 10 pounds since being laid off from her job with Citibank. ''With the flexibility that my schedule has given me, I can go to the gym more often, I
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pulled out a narrow re-election victory on Tuesday, as voters angry over his maneuver to undo the city's term limits law and his extravagant campaign spending provided an unexpected lift to his vastly underfinanced challenger, William C. Thompson Jr. Unofficial returns showed Mr. Bloomberg with 51 percent and Mr. Thompson
title: BLOOMBERG WINS 3RD TERM IN TIGHT RACE; Thompson Strong in Campaign for Mayor

body: IN a city of 8.2 million people, where most apartment buildings are a stack of identical boxes, it's surprising how radically different those boxes can be on the inside, once they've been altered to suit personal tastes. But unlike homes in small towns or cities -- which are often single-story and therefore relatively easy for passersby to peer
title: The Renovation Trifecta: 1 Building, 3 Floors

body: International UNITED NATIONS CONDEMNS U.S. Embargo Against Cuba The United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly to condemn the American trade embargo against Cuba, with speeches by the U.S. ambassador and Cuba's foreign minister reflecting how little has changed despite an expected shift under the Obama administration. PAGE A8 SPREAD OF
title: Inside the Times

body: 'GHOULS AND GOURDS' Don't expect candy at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's Halloween celebration on Sunday. Or jack-o'-lanterns. Or, for that matter, ghouls, even though the event is called ''Ghouls and Gourds.'' ''We want kids to think outside the box,'' said Anita Jacobs, the garden's director of public programs. (And well outside the trick-or-treat
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Looking Ahead HILL COUNTRY CHICKEN In the spring, Hill Country, the Texas barbecue restaurant and market, will open this spot for fried chicken and Southern baked goods: 1123 Broadway (25th Street). Opening This Week CORSINO Jason Denton has scored with his panini and wine places, 'Ino and 'Inoteca. His latest, which opened Oct. 19, varies the
title: Off The Menu

body: BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real
title: When Love Is a Schlep

body: WHEN they married last November, Mike and Sarah Hudnall had two plans for the near future: a new home and a new baby. They assumed there would be sufficient time to hunt for the former while waiting for the latter to happen. Instead, Mrs. Hudnall became pregnant immediately, so finding a place to buy became a priority. In their cozy Park Slope,
title: THE HUNT; New Home, New Addition

title: Calendar

body: KIM STOLZ, a green-eyed brunette whose résumé includes a star turn on ''America's Next Top Model'' as well as a stint at a major New York law firm, lives in an Upper East Side apartment that embodies the geography of her childhood. It was in this two-bedroom penthouse aerie on East 84th Street, near Third Avenue, that Ms. Stolz, now 26, used to
title: HABITATS | EAST 84TH STREET; A Hand-Me-Down Home

body: TEN years is a respectable run for a New York restaurant. Most don't make it that long, and many of those that do are slowly taking on water. A few may change course by bringing a new chef on board or, more and more frequently these days, trimming their sails and tacking toward cheaper, more casual shores. Saul is a heartening exception. One of the
title: RESTAURANTS; Still Neighborly in Brooklyn

Saturday, 10 a.m. to 12:30 p.m., a bicycle tour of historical and architectural sites in the East Bronx; free. Museum hours: Wednesdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m.; grounds open daily, 8:30 a.m. to dusk. 895

body: Mel Vader and Bob Henderson figured that martini hour on the terrace of their apartment in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, would grow only more interesting after Richard Meier built his 15-story glass tower across the way. From their sixth-floor perch, the couple have seen a toddler on the eighth floor ride her tricycle around her balcony, and watched
title: Glass Half Empty

body: Continuing layoffs on Wall Street drove New York City's unemployment rate to 10.3 percent in August, a 16-year high that underscores the need to retrain former financial services workers for other jobs, state officials said Thursday. In the year since the Lehman Brothers investment bank collapsed and others had to be rescued from failing, the
title: CITY JOBLESS RATE CLIMBS TO 10.3%

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: Starting this week, Susan Coronel, a day care owner, plans to leave her home in Ridgewood, Queens, most days at 6:45 a.m. with her 5-year-old son, Benjamin, and drive 10 minutes to Bushwick, Brooklyn. There, a bus hired by a dozen families, at about $400 a month each, will pick up Benjamin and another 5-year-old before stopping at homes in Crown
title: BIG CITY; Going the Distance to Get A Child to a Magnet School

body: Dates are listed when known: ABE & ARTHUR'S Mark Birnbaum and Michael Hirtenstein have named this restaurant for grandfathers and are building a dining room for Franklin Becker's grill menu on the ground floor of the former Lotus. A lounge is named Simyone after a grandfather of another partner, Eugene Remm: 409 West 14th Street. Late September. A

body: These restaurants will open starting in October: BALABOOSTA The name is Yiddish for the perfect housewife. So Einat Admony, the chef and an owner of Taim, will let passers-by peer into the kitchen through a window on the street. There will be references to North Africa and the Middle East: 214 Mulberry Street (Spring Street). December. B CLINTON
title: Opening Later

body: As a rising number of half-finished and half-empty condo projects clutter the skyline, state and city officials have begun developing programs to turn hundreds of these apartments into moderate-income housing. But those efforts have proved far from easy. With budgets tighter than ever, there are few financial incentives to entice developers and
title: City Seeks to Turn Stalled Projects Into Moderate-Income Housing

body: THE NIGHT KEEPER Orrin Harris, 48, sleeps during the day and spends nights cooking, cleaning, speaking with her mother on the telephone and ''looking out for the building'' in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where she has lived for nearly 30 years. Around 4:30 a.m., she takes a bike ride through Prospect Park, then showers and goes to bed. ''I hide
title: One in 8 Million New York Characters in Sound and Images

body: ANGER 'POSTED' The Age-Old Way Robert Keith doesn't tweet. He doesn't blog. He doesn't post comments on the Web. Mr. Keith, 75, prefers a distinctly lo-fi medium: the window poster. Every couple of weeks, he props two professionally made signs in his first-floor windows. Subjects of his contempt have included credit default swaps, auto bailouts and
title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: QUESTIONS upon questions upon questions: they're a restaurant critic's real diet, fed to him by friends and strangers, in phone calls and e-mail messages, at cocktail parties and the gym. Say the words, ''I'm a restaurant critic,'' and the floodgates open. ''Where should I take my 92-year-old grandmother for brunch in Midtown, keeping in mind that
title: RESTAURANTS; Good Tips at the End of His Meals

body: Two children fell out of windows in separate accidents in Brooklyn over two days. One of the children died of his injuries on Tuesday, and the other remained hospitalized in critical condition, the authorities said. The first accident occurred about 5 p.m. Monday when an 18-month-old boy fell out of a second-story window of a relative's house in
title: 2 Toddlers Fall From Windows in Brooklyn; One Is Dead

body: DMC USA D.J. FINALS Beck and Kanye West are musicians who on the surface have little in common. Beck is a subgenre-hopping rock musician who first gained notice with the depression-inducing song ''Loser,'' while Kanye West's real-life chest-thumping boasts are almost as memorable as those in his rhymes. But when looking for accompaniment to their
title: Spare Times

body: A night of music and dancing at a block party in Brooklyn ended in violence on Saturday night when two men were fatally shot in a car parked nearby, the police said. The men, Vance Rock, 23, and Darian Delk, 19, both of Brooklyn, were shot just after 10 p.m. while sitting in a Chevrolet Caprice at Washington Avenue and St. Johns Place in Prospect
title: Two Men Fatally Shot Near Block Party in Brooklyn

body: INDISCRIMINATE gluttons and discerning gourmands alike have long been crazy for pizza. But over the last few years, they have elevated their passion to a vocation, sending pizza into a whole new stratosphere of respect. It isn't just loved, and it isn't just devoured. It's scrutinized and fetishized, with a Palin-esque power to polarize. Does a
title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Crust Is a Canvas for Pizza's New Wave

body: 1. MOTORINO319 Graham Avenue (Devoe Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn; (718) 599-8899. Pros: Properly cooked Neapolitan crusts with character and no soupiness. Well-balanced toppings in classical and inventive veins. Good beers, well-priced wines, dessert. Cons: Never achieves utter transcendence, and trusted scouts report inconsistency from night to
title: The Best New-Generation Pizzerias

body: Opening This Week AUREOLE This restaurant, formerly on the Upper East Side, made its debut June 29 in its spacious new location. Declaring four-hour dinners passé, Charlie Palmer, its chef and owner, and Christopher Lee, at right, his executive chef, offer a four-course tasting menu of two dishes per course, $115 in the main dining room. title: Off the Menu

body: IT was a recent spring afternoon in Brooklyn, but at Complete Music Studios in Prospect Heights a sweet high voice and a slinky, imperturbable backbeat conjured mid-1970s Memphis. Maxwell, the R&B songwriter who made three platinum albums before he paused his career for seven years, was rehearsing his band for an extended tour timed to the release
title: MUSIC; After a Pause, Maxwell's Music Is Set to Play

body: Opening This Week AVENUE What was Earth is now a multistory lounge owned by Noah Tepperberg and Jason Strauss, partners in Marquee. It opens at 9 p.m. with a menu of finger food like lobster rolls, spring rolls, Kobe sliders and waffle fries by Roblé Ali, all neatly served in woven boxes ($9 to $14): 116 10th Avenue, (17th Street), (212) 337-0054.
title: Off the Menu

body: Will the Nets ever play basketball in Brooklyn? The question is impossible to answer nearly six years since Bruce C. Ratner hatched the idea when he led the successful bid to acquire the Nets for $300 million. Since then, the Mets, the Yankees and the Devils have moved into new homes -- but the Nets still play at the Izod Center in East Rutherford,
title: ANALYSIS; Barriers to Brooklyn Fall Slowly for Nets

body: THERE was a time, not long ago in the grand scheme of things, when the only practical way to get in and out of Greenpoint was by boat. In those days, as late as the mid-19th century, the area was separated from much of the rest of Brooklyn by marshland and flanked on the north and west by Newtown Creek and the East River. Overland crossings were
title: LIVING IN | GREENPOINT, BROOKLYN; Polish Is Still Spoken, but Industry Is History

body: Open Now AAMCHI PAO Ever have an Indian slider? Surbhi Sahni, left, the pastry chef at Dévi, and Nandini Mukherjee, right, who owned Indian Bread Co., will be glad to serve you one at their new spot. Ms. Sahni said the name means ''my bread'' in Maharashtri. Pao are like burger buns but smaller and can be filled with potato fritter, crisped
title: Off the Menu

body: THE tedious 35-minute subway ride between David Basner's studio in Chelsea and Courtney Reimer's one-bedroom in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, annoyed both of them. Each disliked the other's place, too. She felt that his -- so small it fit only a twin bed -- was cramped and dark. He felt that hers was inconvenient and impractical. Except for maybe a
title: THE HUNT; A Place They Both Call Home

body: THEY said nothing could replace Mooney's Pub. For almost a year, they were right. The old bar, which had stood on Flatbush Avenue near Seventh Avenue in Prospect Heights since before Brooklyn was fashionable, closed in a rent dispute last June, after a rollicking Saturday night when the air-conditioning broke and people crowded in anyway. The next
title: DISPATCHES; A Bar -- a Bar! -- Where the Pub Used to Be

title: A Historic District Is Proposed, and Buildings Are Soon Altered

Over the last six years, the juried show, which features contemporary furnishings, lighting and accessories designed, and in most
title: Made in Brooklyn

body: AROUND TOWN TRANSLATION SLAM Translation is a tricky business. You never know exactly where, or how, you're going to end up. In ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' when Bottom, in his ass's head, is told ''thou art translated!,'' he has not only been physically transformed but also magically intoxicated, transmigrated to another world. In the
title: Spare Times

title: New York City

body: THE season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, when visitors are invited into skinny row houses, sprawling apartments and vast estates to study their gleaming kitchens, burnished woodwork, antiques and artworks and city or country views. Unless otherwise noted, tours are self-guided; details may change, so check with a tour's
title: Homes and Gardens, Open for Gawking

body: LOTS of New Yorkers dream of discovering an extra room in their apartments. For Gandalf Gaván and Nicola López, that dream came true, and then some. title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Look, Kids! A Secret Room!

body: LIVING at home with Mom and Dad at age 34? Oh, the indignity. All he could think, Quamin Ellis said, was, ''I can't do this -- I'm an adult.'' But it was even more unacceptable to pay rent. So Mr. Ellis opted for delayed gratification. If he had to return to the parental nest, he would, holding out until he could again buy an apartment. After
title: THE HUNT; Leaving the Nest (Again)

body: ARTISTIC and romantic partnerships are tricky things, susceptible to envy, one-upmanship and other dysfunctions, but Bradley Rust Gray and So Yong Kim, New York-based independent filmmakers who have been married for 10 years, have hit on a working method that is both equitable and harmonious. Each is a director with two movies apiece so far, and
title: Independently Intimate Directors

body: 'FOOD IN FILM: An Evening of Flavors From the Silver Screen' Good films, like good lasagna, are artfully layered productions, filled with metaphors and surprises. How filmmakers develop food scenes will be tastefully dissected on Wednesday night in this program at the 92nd Street Y, part of the series Francine Segan's World of Tasting. Ms. Segan, a
title: Spare Times

body: VERA BEAUDIN SAEEDPOUR talks about her home as it if she met it on a blind date and didn't know what hit her. One minute she's checking it out, and the next thing she knows she's settling in. ''I walked in and looked around -- just the entrance -- and I said, 'I'll take it.' '' But then, few events in Dr. Saeedpour's life seem calm, orderly or
title: HABITATS | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; The Home As Cultural Refuge

body: When a woman set down a vision for her Brooklyn neighborhood on her blog last month, she did not know how popular it would become. ''The goal is to sow wildflower seeds on every single patch of abandoned soil,'' Deborah Fisher, an artist who lives in Bedford-Stuyvesant, wrote on March 7. ''I want there to be so many wildflowers on the streets that
title: April Showers Bring Seed-Sowing Volunteers

body: WHEN it comes to the recession, tactful New Yorkers may refrain from complaining too loudly about their misfortunes, knowing that the chances are, there is someone else out there who has it worse. But try explaining to a 6-year-old, no matter how worldly and well mannered, that budget cuts may prevent him from spending quality time with a penguin.
title: CONEY ISLAND; A Small Casualty In Hard Times

title: ON THE MARKET; PROSPECT HEIGHTS STUDIO

body: BEHOLD the power of the collective unconscious: ''In Treatment,'' HBO's intimate and innovative therapy drama, has resurfaced in its second season as a show both shot and set in the talking-cure capital, New York City. What's more, its central character, the boundary-challenged, deeply conflicted, terribly appealing psychotherapist Paul Weston
title: TELEVISION; Sessions and the Single Man

title: Spare Times

body: AS a teenager, Carla Ford-Anderson would walk past the enormous apartment building on Eastern Parkway in Prospect Heights, opposite Prospect Park, and wonder what it would be like to live there. In 1976, married to her first husband, she found out, renting a two-bedroom two-and-a-half bath apartment. In 1980 the building went co-op, and the couple
title: THE SELL | PROSPECT HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN; Listening to Your Broker Can Pay Off

body: AN ugly red statuette of a bull appeared last month on a shelf at O'Connor's, a sparsely decorated watering hole in Park Slope. Most of O'Connor's drinkers knew that the bull would fit in better at Freddy's Bar, a few blocks away in Prospect Heights. That's because the bull was, in fact, pilfered from Freddy's. The prank, carried out by an
title: PARK SLOPE | PROSPECT HEIGHTS; Pranksters Amid the Pilsner

body: AROUND TOWN USA MEMORY CHAMPIONSHIP When Proust bit into that madeleine, he eventually located the source of the rosy childhood recollection -- Sunday tea with an aunt -- that gave the treat an appeal beyond its undoubtedly generous quantity of sugar. Impressive. But for the participants in the 12th annual memory championship the task that was
title: SPARE TIMES

body: AROUND TOWN WILLIAMSBURG SPELLING BEE True confession time: I'm a spelling nerd. I won my junior high bee, have been known to take a rooting interest in the national finals on television and, as an editor, depend to a certain extent on my ability to spell. Still, even for me, the prospect of spending a night out just, well, spelling didn't sound
title: Spare Times

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: By February's standards, Thursday was practically balmy in New York City. But it was still too cold for stoop-sitting. So Kimber VanRy will wait a few months before deciding whether to test once more the law's tolerance for someone who sits on his front steps watching the world go by while -- gasp! -- sipping a beer. For some New Yorkers, Mr. VanRy
title: NYC; Testing a Law? He'll Pop a Top and Drink to That

body: TO get the slightly battered convection oven for their new Brooklyn chocolate factory, Rick and Michael Mast traded 250 chocolate bars. The chocolate is as good as legal tender for Andrew Tarlow and Mark Firth, owners of Marlow & Sons, the restaurant and specialty shop that bartered away the oven. ''We can't keep it in stock,'' Mr. Tarlow said.
title: Now in Brooklyn, the 19th Century

body: The Clinton Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn thuds to a halt at Atlantic Avenue; Prospect Heights starts a few blocks south. But now there is a storefront between gas stations and warehouses there that looks as if it were transported intact from Paris. Choice Atlantic, its burgundy facade lettered à la Française, is a new food store owned by Thierry
title: FOOD STUFF; Food on a Grand Scale

title: The Listings: Feb.6 - Feb. 12 | Jazz

body: ''Here,'' said Eddie Byrnes. He waved his hand at a bare wall in a wholesale food warehouse in Brooklyn. ''This is where they usually keep the wings,'' said Mr. Byrnes, who buys food for the Kettle Black Bar and Restaurant in Bay Ridge. He squinted at a stack of boxes nearby that were full of chicken parts, all of them wrong. Drumsticks. Breasts.
title: ABOUT NEW YORK; A Super Bowl Victory, Answering a Prayer for Wings

body: LIKE any worthwhile journey through New York, the television drama ''Life on Mars'' takes a roundabout route to arrive at a familiar destination. In its first episode, a New York police detective named Sam Tyler is hit by a car. When Tyler, played by the actor Jason O'Mara, recovers from the accident, he finds he has woken up in the year 1973. He
title: Law and Disorder

body: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) PRAYERS FOR BOBBY (2009) In her first television movie Sigourney Weaver, at right with Ryan Kelley, plays Mary Griffith, a religious suburban housewife in the 1970s who struggles to accept that her son Bobby (Mr. Kelley) is gay. When tragedy results, Griffith becomes an advocate for gay rights. The film is based on the nonfiction

body: For the first time, a reality show set in New York is about to unleash the tide of jealousy, voyeurism and scorn always latent in this city's overeducated, undercompensated sectors. ''The Apprentice,'' ''Project Runway,'' ''Real Housewives,'' ''Top Chef'' and ''The Real World'' have left the local consciousness largely undisturbed. But New York has
title: TELEVISION REVIEW | 'THIS OLD HOUSE'; Now Building in Brooklyn: A Renovation, Maybe Envy

body: LUNAR NEW YEAR The passage of time is maddeningly subjective -- a minute in traffic is never quite like a minute in front of the television -- and that is perhaps one reason people endlessly seek to measure it. History is littered with calendars that didn't survive (remember the Calendrier républicain, anyone?). But one that was too entrenched,
title: SPARE TIMES

body: In its 29 years on the air, ''This Old House,'' the PBS renovation program, has ventured beyond its Massachusetts roots to Miami, New Orleans and even Santa Barbara, but has studiously avoided New York City. Starting Jan. 22, though, the show will broadcast from Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, where Karen Shen and Kevin Costello (above, with their
title: CURRENTS | ON TV; In New York, It's 'That Old Brownstone'

body: ''I'M really a modernist,'' said Serine Hastings, who lived in prewar apartments her first three decades in New York. Since moving from Chicago in the late 1970s, she has always made her home in places with vintage architectural details. ''I lived on the top floor of a Federal town house in Chelsea and a co-op on the Upper West Side,'' said Ms.
title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; After All Those Brownstones, a Blank Canvas

body: '50 FIRST JOKES' Eating black-eyed peas, being hung over, regrets -- everyone has a New Year's tradition. For the show ''50 First Jokes'' on Saturday, 50 comedians will start 2009 with a new punch line. ''Our rule is, you have to write your joke after the ball drops,'' said Jiwon Lee, a stand-up comedian and co-producer of the event, now in its
title: SPARE TIMES: AROUND TOWN

body: Jolene Siana, a writer in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, plans to spend time with friends at their homes rather than in wine bars, bringing a $12 bottle rather than blowing $12 on a glass. title: As Resolutions Go, Spending Less May Actually Stick
